citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The licensee has never sent a written itinerary for overnight exhibition and travel. The licensee exhibited his spider
monkey “Ceasar” at the Kalamazoo Women’s Lifestyle Expo in Kalamazoo Michigan on March 22 and 23, 2024. The
licensee has not provided Animal Care any information pertaining to any such exhibition of the animals away from his site.
Inspectors have notified the licensee numerous times that a written itinerary must be sent if overnight exhibition will take
place away from the approved home site, and for overnight travel. The licensee is also exhibiting from an unapproved
site. The itinerary is required so that inspectors can inspect the licensee’s compliance with the Animal Welfare Act
regulations (AWA), such as for transportation and handling of animals.
Any person who is subject to the AWA and who intends to exhibit any animal at any location other than the person’s
approved site (including, but not limited to, circuses, traveling educational exhibits, animal acts, and petting zoos), except
for travel that does not extend overnight, shall submit a written itinerary to the Deputy Administrator. The itinerary shall be
received by the Deputy Administrator no fewer than 2 days in advance of any travel and shall contain complete and
accurate information concerning the whereabouts of any animal intended for exhibition at any location other than the
person’s approved site.

The licensee exhibited his spider monkey “Ceasar” at the Kalamazoo Women’s Lifestyle Expo in Kalamazoo Michigan on
March 22 and 23, 2024. During this exhibition, the licensee had “Ceasar” in a harness with a leash attached. On March
22, 2024 “Ceasar” bit a seven-year-old child. Medical attention was sought at a local hospital for the bite wound. Neither
barriers nor effective direct control was in use and without them, a member of the public was injured, and the spider
monkey could have been in risk of harm or injury.
There must be a barrier between a mobile or traveling housing facility and the public at any time the public is present, in
order to restrict physical contact between the nonhuman primates and the public. Nonhuman primates used in traveling
exhibits, trained animal acts, or in uncaged public exhibits must be under the direct control and supervision of an
experienced handler or trainer at all times when the public is present. Trained nonhuman primates may be allowed
physical contact with the public, but only if they are under the direct control and supervision of an experienced handler or
trainer at all times during the contact to minimize the risk of harm to the animal and to the public. The licensee must
assure that these means of protecting the animals being exhibited and the public are used at all times while exhibiting.
This inspection was a site approval inspection.
This site is not ready for approval to conduct activity covered under your current Animal Welfare Act License.
Conducting regulated activities at a non-approved site is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next new site approval inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
